abstract.text: The production of heavy quarks in pp collisions at the LHC energies provides a reliable test of perturbative QCD calculations.
Comparisons of pp and p-Pb measurements of their hadronization products allow us to investigate how cold nuclear matter effects affect the heavy-quark production.
We present ALICE measurements of azimuthal correlations of prompt D mesons with charged hadrons in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV and p-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 5.02 TeV.
We also show the per-event D-meson yields as a function of the charged-particle multiplicity in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV.

body_text.text: Introduction
The study of heavy-flavor production in pp collisions at LHC energies allows us to test perturbative QCD calculations and provides a reference for studies in heavy-ion collisions.

body_text.text: Summary

The self-normalized D-meson yields as a function of the charged-particle multiplicity, measured by ALICE in pp collisions, show a faster-than-linear increase with multiplicity, in fair agreement with ex- pectations from models including MPI contribution to particle production.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The D meson-charged particle azimuthal correlation distributions, measured in pp and p-Pb collisions, are in agreement between each other within uncertainties, and are well described by Monte Carlo expectations.
